M. E. BUILDING GRAVEYARD
FOR FAMOUS OLD MACHINES
Hidden in the recesses of the
attic of the M. E. Building are
the evidences of years of careful
research and relics of a past age
of scientific activity. An array
of metal discs, wheels and odds
and ends of machinery gave to
the place the atmosphere of a
grave-yard for the tools of accomplished researches.
The curious one paused and examined the interesting scene. A
simple looking machine, dusty
and tarnished by age, had a familiar appearance. A closer inspection disclosed its identity.
It was Rowland's apparatus for
determining
the
Mechanical
Equivalent of Heat.
What was once a masterpiece
of mechanical skill was stripped
to its essentials. The nickelplated calorimeter, the chronograph, and numerous accessories
had disappeared. The framework
with its vertical shaft and brass
circles, the perfectly meshed
gears, and one lonely pulley displaced from its bearings, were all
that one saw •of the famous device. It had long since served its
day in adding another victory to
the career of Henry A. Rowland,
America's greatest physicist.

Just forty seven years ago, he
began his first experiments to redetermine this most important
physical constant. The problem
of determining its value had interested scientists for a century.
In , 1798.a rough.value -was obtained by Count Rumford. The most
extended work was done by
Joule, the English physicist, who
experimented from 1845 to 1878.
Others tried the problem with
the result that thirty seven values of the constant had been published when Rowland resolved to
settle the discrepancy once for all.
He began his elaborate research
in January, 1878, two years after
he accepted the chair of physics
at the newly-formed University.
He used the paddle-wheel method
of Joule, but he improved the apparatus to a degree never before
attained. Rowland's love for accuracy led him to take. the most
painstaking measu-res to eliminate
every error which might affect his
results. Studies in thermometry
and the specific heat of water
were simultaneously conducted
with the investigation of the mechanical equivalent of heat. His
determinations were conclusive.
They have withstood the tests of
fifty years of practice.'

FOR FAMOUS OLD MACHINES
Hidden in the recesses of the
attic of the M. E. Building are
the evidences of years of careful
research and relics of a past age
of scientific activity. An array
of metal discs, wheels and odds
and ends of machinery gave to
the place the atmosphere of a
grave-yard for the tools of accomplished researches.
The curious one paused and examined the interesting scene. A
simple looking machine, dusty
and tarnished by age, had a familiar appearance. A closer inspection disclosed its identity.
It was Rowland's apparatus for
determining
the
Mechanical
Equivalent of Heat.
What was once a masterpiece
of mechanical skill was stripped
to its essentials. The nickelplated calorimeter, the chronograph, and numerous accessories
had disappeared. The framework
with its vertical shaft and brass
circles, the perfectly meshed
gears, and one lonely pulley displaced from its bearings, were all
that one saw •of the famous device. It had long since served its
day in adding another victory to
the career of Henry A. Rowland,
America's greatest physicist.

Just forty seven years ago, he
began his first experiments to redetermine this most important
physical constant. The problem
of determining its value had interested scientists for a century.
In , 1798.a rough.value -was obtained by Count Rumford. The most
extended work was done by
Joule, the English physicist, who
experimented from 1845 to 1878.
Others tried the problem with
the result that thirty seven values of the constant had been published when Rowland resolved to
settle the discrepancy once for all.
He began his elaborate research
in January, 1878, two years after
he accepted the chair of physics
at the newly-formed University.
He used the paddle-wheel method
of Joule, but he improved the apparatus to a degree never before
attained. Rowland's love for accuracy led him to take. the most
painstaking measu-res to eliminate
every error which might affect his
results. Studies in thermometry
and the specific heat of water
were simultaneously conducted
with the investigation of the mechanical equivalent of heat. His
determinations were conclusive.
They have withstood the tests of
fifty years of practice.'
